fn.p: Predatory gastropods living in cold environments may take up to 20 times longer—weeks instead of days—to drill through the shells of their prey than species adapted to warm water environments [ 13].

The taxonomy of the family Naticidae from the La Meseta Formation is not yet fully resolved (see [ 21, appendix S2, p. 24]). The two most-abundant species in the LMF were designated as Polinices cf. subtenius and P. marambioensis by Stillwell and Zinsmeister [ 22]. However, Crame et al. [ 21], in their recent, comprehensive overview of the molluscan fauna of the LMF, including much of the material treated in this study and additional collections housed at the British Antarctic Survey, concluded that these species should be assigned to the genus Falsilunatia ( figure 1 c; see [ 23, p. 216], which is commonly found in Antarctic waters today [ 24]. Crame et al. [ 21] further stated that P. marambioensis is highly unlikely to be a distinct species from P. cf. subtenuis. Two other naticid taxa, Eunaticina infrequens and Sinuber powelli, were described by Stillwell and Zinsmeister [ 22]; however, only a single individual of each of these rare species was identified in the material we examined for this study. Thus, we are confident that the predatory drillholes we found on the shells of Falsilunatia n. sp. were made by conspecific cannibals.

The possibility that a lack of alternative prey may influence the frequency of cannibalism was recently raised by Brezina et al. [ 9] for Falsilunatia n. sp. (identified by the authors as P. marambionensis) from the upper part of the Cucullaea I Allomember (=Telm 5 in this study) of the LMF. They found cannibalism attack frequencies that were approximately 2−3 times greater than those reported in this study and speculated that ‘the low relative abundance of other possible prey … could have affected … naticid behaviour’ [ 9, p. 213]. However, the Brezina et al. [ 9] samples—unlike those used in this study—came from a tidal channel deposit composed of ‘densely packed shell concentrations’, which were dominated by specimens of Falsilunatia n. sp., with low abundances of other taxa.
